titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Arvid Paulson Papers
1875-1977
MSS 043
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Maxime de la Fantasie, 1999

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from paulson.doc

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2009-05-07T15:48-0400

did.abstract: The Arvid Paulson Papers represent Paulson's attempts to bring the work of August Strindberg and Henrik Ibsen to a twentieth century American public. The collection contains his correspondence with actors, publishers and producers, the manuscripts of his translations, some of his published criticism on Strindberg and Ibsen as well as that of other authors. Finally, it contains miscellaneous theatre memorabilia culled from a long life spent going to the theatre, perfoming in plays and occasionally even producing them himself.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Arvid Paulson donated his collection of rare and first editions of August Strindberg's writings to the Fales Library in 1970. His papers, consisting of eight linear feet of correspondence, manuscripts, printed material and memorabilia, were given over a period of years from 1970 until his death in Malmo, Sweden, in 1977.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments must be made in advance to view archival or manuscript materials.

bioghist.head: Biography of Arvid Paulson
bioghist.p: Arvid Paulson (1888-1977) was an author, translator and actor. Born in Helsingborg, Sweden, he emigrated to the United States in 1904. Though he performed in many plays written by Strindberg and Ibsen, he is perhaps best known as a translator of their work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p:
Series I: Correspondence contains Paulson's correspondence with various producers, actors and publishers, 1917-1977.
Series II: Manuscripts contains the manuscripts for Paulson's translations of Ibsen, Strindberg and other Scandinavian writers; it also contains Paulson's collection of Ibsen ephemera.
Series III: Publications contains Paulson's and other writers' published articles about Strindberg.
Series IV: Printed Matter and Memorabilia contains programs, playbills, photographs and miscellaneous other material relating to productions of Strindberg's and Ibsen's plays in Sweden and America, as well as more generally to the twentieth century American theatre.
Series V: Paulson contains some of Paulson's personal papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection has been organized into five Series. Each series initiates a new numbering sequence. Oversize material is listed toward the end of the collection.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: In addition to the material found here, Arvid Paulson also donated some 350 books and articles by and about Strindberg and Henrik Ibsen to the Fales Library. The following books and articles have been separated from the collection and are individually catalogued through BobCat.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Arvid Paulson Papers; MSS 043; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Paulson and various directors, producers, actors, and publishers, 1916-1974.

Correspondence between Paulson and Ben-Ali Bobker, re: The 1952 Pasadena Playhouse production of Strindberg's "The Great Highway"

Correspondence from various actors and writers
Correspondence from Paulson, re: Strindberg Society, Strindberg statue, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series II contains the mss. of Paulson's translations of Henrik Ibsen, August Strindberg and other Scandinavian authors. Subseries A contains Paulson's translations of Ibsen, as well as miscellaneous Ibsen ephemera collected by Paulson; the ephemera includes playbills, postcards and criticism. Series II, Subseries B contains Paulson's mss. translations of Strindberg; subseries C contains the same material, this time in drafts prepared for publication. Subseries D contains Paulson's translations of Vilhelm Moberg, Knut Hamsun, Gustav Geijerstam and other Scandinavian authors. Subseries E contains miscellaneous manuscripts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series III contains criticism and translations published by Paulson and other writers in Swedish and American periodicals. Subseries A contains Paulson's articles on Strindberg, as well as Paulson's translations of Strindberg, Selma Lagerlof and Arvid Skappel. Subseries B contains articles on Strindberg and on Strindberg studies by other authors, as well as a 1913 translation of Strindberg's "Half a Sheet of Paper.

Series IV: Printed Matter and Memorabilia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series IV contains playbills, photographs, tickets, press clippings and other material from Paulson's life as a producer, performer and theater-goer; in addition it contains publicity material for his books and misc. Strindberg memorabilia. Subseries A contains playbills, photographs and tickets from performances of Strindberg's plays in Sweden and America, 1918-1979; Paulson either acted in or supplied the translations for some of these productions. Subseries A also contains misc. material from Paulson's life in the theatre, such as a 1941 manual for theatre staff and an assortment of actors' periodicals. Subseries B contains Strindberg memorabilia.

scopecontent.p: Series V contains Paulson's personal papers: photographs, awards, the mss. of a biography, calling cards and misc. legal papers.

scopecontent.p: This series contains oversize material from the entire collection. Folders have been numbered according to the series sequence.
